emotions: first, a noble Matron
whose weeping displayed her grief,
there nearby, with artful practice,
an openly bright Female character,
laughing amiably with a cheerful tone,
which (they say) he copied after the courtesan
Phryne, who was greatly celebrated.

39. It seemed that in her face one could detect
his desire for her, and the great delight
she summoned in his sense.
But Demon the Athenian, because of his colors
an excellent painter in his day,
His Figures seemed to appear, variously,
as inconstant, raging, angry, good-natured, gentle,
fearful, proud, humble, and grand.
right-middleDemon was artful in depicting the emotions; read his Life.

40. Indeed, he strove to depict
various emotions together in a single Figure:
Timanthes of Cyprus also rose to fame
having painted, as required,
the great sorrow and lamentation
when Iphigenia, the maiden whom they intended
to slay as an innocent sacrifice,
was brought before the stone Altar

41. To propitiate the outraged Diana
and subdue the rushing storms of the Sea;
There were those who were to accomplish the deed,
Also bystanders with a compassionate air,
Calcas could be seen full of sorrows,
while even more afflicted was Ulysses,
her Uncle, stricken to the heart
by the horrible, murderous offering.

42. When the Painter had best used
all the sorrowful gestures,
hand-wringing, weeping, and wailing,
he had at last powerfully painted,
standing out above all,
Agamemnon, the Father, in such despair and helplessness,
that he could not endure to watch
the cruel death-blow to his Child

43. He accomplished this by covering his face
with his clothes, or with his hands.
There have been various verses and Poetic works
composed about this artful work,
bring it glorious renown in distant Lands.
One could always detect some
Hidden ideas in his works;
he surpassed Colotes and Demon.
